I think it lets you perform a maneuver in multiple passes, so you take advantage of the oberth effect, especially if you have weak thrusters (i.e. nuke and ion engines). It could probably also be quite useful for rendezvous-ing, but I like to let the computer (MechJeb) do that and docking for me. For me, Docking = Running out of monopropellant and finger cramps (the docking controls make no sense! And I'm pretty sure nobody uses docking mode since you can't rotate easily). 

This mod is definitely a must-have for anyone who uses low-TWR vessels!

Yes, I believe the mod is to aid in multiple orbit raising maneuvers (between launch and "departure") such as used on the MOM (image not to scale):

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mars_Orbiter_Mission#Orbit_raising_manoeuvres

Edit: The idea of splitting up such maneuvers, as hieywiey points out, is to fully exploit the Oberth effect. This is of particular usefulness if the thrust to mass ratio is low.

1 hour ago, maceemiller said:

Alas I still have no idea so think I'll pass on this mod.

It's most useful for craft with really low TWR, where the burn times to go interplanetary hits 30+ minutes.

With long burns you have to do half the burn before you reach the node and half after, which means you have to start 15+ minutes before the maneuver node. But if you try to do that from a low orbit (80-120 km), where orbit times are less than 40 minutes, you'd be almost at the opposite side of the planet, burning almost retrograde. So you'd be deorbiting yourself instead of going interplanetary.

What this mod does for you, is split a large burn like that up into several smaller burns, so you can do interplanetary travel from low orbit with low TWR.

It's much more efficient than the alternative, going to a higher orbit, where orbit times are long enough that a 30+ minute burn wouldn't cause you to burn retrograde.

I think this mod could also be useful for gravity assist redirect maneuvers when, for instance, you have to burn radially to redirect the orbital path of the vessel to arrive at another planet, isn't it?

It's just a theory of mine and I've never tried it on ksp (because I didn't exit the kerbin system yet).

I'd like to know if that is actually true, so please reply to me.

The other use is to split the burn for used ascend stages.

For instance, I design a lander on top of a nuke based tug. And below the tug, I have the booster stage to put it in LKO. But once I reach LKO, that booster still has some fuel left (say, a half filled Kerbodyne tank with a Mammoth or Rhino engine). If I'm not trying to recover that stage, the first burn could be just that stage.

And then, when I stage and have the nuclear tug, the burn time will be accurate (and shorter)
This seems like a cool mod, I've only used nukes once and it didn't end well because the burns were so long- this looks promising for a noob like myself!
Excellent idea for a mod.

For those who tried doing a 30 minute nuke burn from Kerbin orbit by burning in the maneuver direction 15 minutes early (and then being surprised about deorbiting), a better way is simply burning prograde, starting a few minutes before the maneuver node. The ship won't precisely follow the planned maneuver trajectory, but it will get away from Kerbin with the desired speed and (hopefully) more or less in the desired direction. Use quicksave/load to get as close as possible to the desired ejection angle. If I remember correctly, my 30 minute burn for Jool required a prograde burn starting around 3 or 4 minutes before the maneuver node just to give you an idea of the order of magnitude.

I believe there's also a mod for that, by the way, but I don't know which one. (MechJeb can't, at least not yet).

Separate burns to maximize the oberth effect are of course even better, but it takes a lot of patience. This mod may help with that, I haven't tried it but at first sight it seems like a good idea.

9 hours ago, 0111narwhalz said:

Well...Brachistochrone means burning the entire travel. And you can do it with any TWR, I think. Pretty sure that ion burns qualify as brachistochrone. What you have here is fine for a high-TWR, high-∆V burn that's relatively short. It's not the scenario I'm talking about.

Well, yes, you could do a constant thrust trajectory (I think that's what you mean by Brachistochrone) for the whole Kerbin escape, even with high TWR crafts, merely by reducing the throttle. But that's not the most efficient way to go about it, all else being equal (apples to apples).

But even if you don't have the option to raise the throttle, and are limited to extremely low TWR, it's still more efficient (although perhaps more tedious) to break up the orbit raising burn into many separate burns such that each burn is quite close to periapsis. The idea behind this is that periapsis remains low; only the apoapsis rises. Limiting the burns to short burns near a low periapsis maximizes the Oberth effect.

And it can save a lot of fuel. On a planet like Kerbin, escaping via this all-burns-at-low-periapsis approach might save around 1/3 (maybe even closer to 1/2) the fuel that it would take if you slowly and gradually spiral out of Kerbin's orbit (by "gradually spiraling out of orbit," I mean a constant thrust [i.e., gradual spiral or by moving to higher circular orbits] trajectory).

You can also use this efficient, all-burns-near-periapsis approach for capture on a body like Tylo -- one in which you can't rely on atmospheric braking. [Edit: although I don't know if this mod works on captures. It's just the strategy I'm referring to here.]

Of course, this only works though when the orbit is still elliptical. As soon as the orbit goes parabolic, there is little/no reason to reduce the burn times. [Edit: Thus it's better to continue to burn on that last periapsis burn (when the hyperbolic orbit is established), for however long it takes -- but do it sooner rather than later. Ideally, you'll keep burning until you get your encounter at your target body, burning as close as possible to the planet/moon which you happen to be escaping (e.g., try to keep that last, final burn as close to Kerbin as possible, if you are escaping Kerbin). Waiting until you escape the escaping body before setting up a maneuver node to get the encounter of your target body is shooting yourself in the foot, efficiency wise.]
